anchor.surface_text: An appeal lies against the adjudication of a High Court as a matter of right, whatever the nature of the proceeding, with certificate that it involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution, and in civil proceeding with certificate of the nature set out in cls.  a ,  b  or  c  of Art. 133 1 , or from any judgment or final order or sentence in a criminal proceeding of a High Court, if the case falls within the description of cls.  a  and  b  of Art. 134, or if the High Court certifies that the case is a fit one for appeal. It is clear that under Art. 136 against the adjudications of all companyrts and tribunals  subject to the exception already numbericed  whatever be the character of the proceeding, appeals lie with leave to this Court. An appeal lies from the judgment, decree or final order of a High Court in a civil, criminal or other proceeding, if the High Court certifies that the case involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution article 132 1 .

arguments.court_reasoning: Civil proceeding includes enforcement of civil rights against tax levy; writ under 226 seeking such relief is civil

arguments.claim: Even if writ proceedings under Article 226 are generally civil, they are not when seeking relief against tax levy

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri for the assessee contended in the first instance that the expression civil proceeding in article 133 only means a proceeding in the nature of or triable as a civil suit and a petition for the issue of a high prerogative writ not being such a proceeding, against the order passed by the High Court no appeal lay to this court with certificate under article 133. In the alternative, counsel contended that even if a proceeding for the issue of a writ under article 226 of the Constitution may in certain cases be treated as a civil proceeding, it cannot be so treated when the party aggrieved seeks relief against the levy of tax or revenue claimed to be due to the State.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ssified as  i  proceedings civil,  ii  proceedings criminal, and  iii  proceedings revenue, and where the case does number involve a substantial quest

arguments.court_reasoning: Tax levy affects civil rights; proceeding to enforce against infringement by tax authorities is civil regardless of form

arguments.claim: Proceeding under Article 226 for writ against tax order is a civil proceeding allowing certification under Article 133

anchor.surface_text: The expression civil proceeding is not defined in the Constitution, not in the General Clauses Act. The expression in our judgment covers all proceedings in which a party asserts the existence of a civil right conferred by the civil law or by statute, and claims relief for breach thereof. A criminal proceeding on the other hand is ordinarily one in which if carried to its conclusion it may result in the imposition of sentences such as death, imprisonment, fine or forfeiture of property. ... A civil proceeding is therefore one in which a person seeks to enforce by appropriate relief the alleged infringement of his civil rights against another person or the State,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proceeding under Art 226 seeking relief against tax levy enforces civil rights infringed by revenue authorities; character depends on right and relief, not form or tribunal; rejects classification of revenue as separate from civil.

holdings.text: the proviso and the rules became effective retrospectively from April 1, 1952.

Mr. Sastri appearing on behalf of the assessee contended that this Court has laid down in T. Cajee v. U. Jormanik Siem that where power is conferred upon an authority and it is made exercisable in the manner provided by subsidiary legislative,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature expressly retrospective from 1.4.1952; rules effectuate proviso and deemed operative retrospectively upon framing; rejects argument no effect till rules.

holdings.text: The case has no application to the present case.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the case cited by counsel for the assessee has any application. That was a case in which a District Council was constituted for the Jaintia. Hill District under the Sixth Schedule to the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Cajee: there absolute power exercisable till restricted by rules; here power conditioned on prescribed cases/circumstances, no absolute power pre-rules.

holdings.text: But the case of the assessee did fall within the terms of rule 48 1 and the Income-tax Officer must in law be bound to consider whether he was entitled to reduction or waiver of interest under the fifth proviso.

anchor.surface_text: That may be so. But the case of the assessee did fall within the terms of rule 48 1 and the Income-tax Officer must in law be bound to consider whether he was entitled to reduction or waiver of interest under the fifth proviso. The amendment and the rules which came into operation later must in view of the retrospective operation be deemed to be then extant,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee's case within rule 48(i); deemed law required consideration of discretion to waive/reduce; non-consideration makes order defective.

holdings.text: The order of the Income-tax Officer which did number take numberice of the law deemed to be in force must be regarded as defective.

anchor.surface_text: and the fact that the Income-tax Officer could not in making the assessment have adjusted his approach to the problem before him in the light of those provisions is irrelevant in considering the legality of his order. The order of the Income-tax Officer which did not take notice of the law deemed to be in force must be regarded as defective.

holdings.reasoning_summary: By deeming provision, ITO had discretion at assessment date; failure to address it renders original order defective, not a mere omission rectifiable later as mistake apparent.

holdings.text: The High Court was therefore right in setting aside the order which was passed by the Commissioner without considering the proviso to S. 18-A  6  which was clearly applicable to the case of the assessee and in the light of A. 48 which was enacted in pursuance of that Proviso.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was brought before the Commissioner of Income-tax and it is unfortunate that the Commissioner in considering the matter under S. 33-A assumed that the amending Act 25 of 1953 had no retrospective operation and rejected the claim of the assessee on the ground that at the date when the order of assessment was made, Act 25 of 1953 had not come into operation,

holdings.reasoning_summary: CIT erred assuming no retrospective effect, overlooking deemed discretion; s35 rectification invalid as omission not apparent mistake but failure to exercise deemed power; confirms HC quashing.

holdings.text: But it cannot be said, having regard specially to paragraph 6, clause  iii , of the petition that in granting relief to the assessee a new case was made out by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Attorney-General contended that the petition filed by the assessee did not expressly seek to plead the case which was ultimately made out by the High Court. It is true that the petition is somewhat vague in setting out the material particulars which have a bearing on the plea which appealed to the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition para 6(iii) covers retrospective discretion argument; not a new case introduced by HC.

anchor.surface_text: T. Cajee v. U. Jormanik Siem that where power is companyferred upon an authority and it is made exercisable in the manner provided by subsidiary legislative, failure top enact such subsidiary legislation will number defeat the power the power will be exercisable without the restrictions which may be, but are number imposed, and therefore once the power of the Income-tax Officer came into being that power became exercisable immediately without restrictions or limitations until the Central Government chose to frame rules defining those restrictions.

precedents.case_name: T Cajee v U Jormanik Siem
precedents.cited_proposition: where power conferred upon authority exercisable by subsidiary legislation, failure to enact does not defeat power; exercisable without restrictions until imposed

Ltd. held in dealing with the case arising under the second proviso to section 18A 5   which was also inserted by Act 25 of 1953 with retrospective operation from April 1, 1952  that the Income-tax Officer has power under section 35 of the Act to rectify a mistake in the assessment, even though the mistake was the result of a legal fiction arising from the retrospective operations given to the amending Act.
